text:

MIT OpenCourseWare

continue to offer high quality
educational resources for free.

To make a donation or to
view additional materials

from hundreds of MIT courses,
visit MIT OpenCourseWare
at ocw.mit.edu.

SEBASTIEN UZEL: All
right, so our group

is going to talk
about the accuracy

requirements in the mechanical
assembly of photonic crystals.

And so to do so,
we'll definitely

have to introduce what
a photonic crystal is.

Then Martin is going to
talk about the fabrication

process of 3D photonic
crystals, and Corey

is going to have this little
application that he carried out

to see the influence of a
misalignment in a 3D structure

on the properties of
photonic crystals.

So an intuitive way to introduce
photonic crystals is to use

the analogy with semiconductors
in electronics because photonic

crystals are to optics
what semiconductors are

to electronics, which means
that in semiconductors,

depending on the
electron energy,

you can or cannot
propagate a current in it.

In photonic crystal, depending
on the frequency of your wave,

you will or will not
propagate waves in it.

And so to understand this
interesting property,

you have to go back
to Maxwell equations.
I'll be quick on this slide.
Don't worry.

But you know that from the
set of the Fourier Maxwell's

equation, you can read it
as an eigenvalue problem

if you assume that your
waves are sinusoidal.

And now, if you introduce
periodicity in your crystal,

and the Bloch theorem
says that you can

rate the magnetic
field like this,

where the k vector
is in the exponential

times a periodic function
where u is a periodic function.

r is the periodicity of
your crystal lattice.

And so the first
eigenvalue problem

becomes this one,
which can be solved

numerically, which is what Corey
has done in the simulations.

And he managed to extract
those eigenvalues, which

are the dispersion relation
between the frequency and the k
vector.

So if we take the example
of a 1D photonic crystal

like this with no
periodicity, which

means that all the permittivity
in the crystal are the same,

equals 1, for example,
we have this relation
which is proportional.

The frequency is
proportional to k.

But now, if you take different
permittivity in the crystal,

you introduce those range of
frequency in which wave cannot
propagate.

And the width, the
size, and the position

of those gaps, the bandgaps, are
a function of the permittivity

or the geometry of your
lattice in the crystal.

Note that we're
only interested--

because of the shape of
those magnetic field,

as exponential of i k r,
then we're only interested--

and because of the
periodicity of the crystal,

we aren't interested in this
small range of k vectors,

from minus k over pi
to plus k over pi.

So to illustrate this
interesting property,

we brought a 1D
photonic crystal which

can only pass blue light,
which means that it will--

the bandgaps are everywhere
where you don't propagate blue,

which you can see if you shine
a-- it's going to be easy.
If you shine blue light--
if you shine-- sorry--

if you illuminate it
with a white light,
you will transmit only blue.
Now, if you shine--

if you illuminate
it with a red light,

then it will block
almost everything,
as you can see on the second--

I don't know if you can see
it, but, basically, there's
nothing to see.

The only problem with
a 1D photonic crystal,

if you shine off-axis, then
it loses this property,

and now you're-- should be
able to see this red spot over
there.

And this is the
reason why people

are trying to now create 2D or
3D photonic crystals, to keep

this property in
all the directions
and with all polarization.

The applications of
photonic crystals are--

well, as you saw, to filter
some of the frequencies,

but also to use it
as a perfect mirror.

And you can also use it
as waveguides or cavities
or light shaping.

And now Martin is going to
talk about the fabrication.

MARTIN DETERRE:
Thank you, Sebastien.

So this really-- photonic
crystals seem very interesting,

but the main problem is,
how can you fabricate them?

So we can throw out lots
of techniques out there,

but we can categorize this
in three main categories.

So first one is a full 3D
fabrication, when you--

where you create the whole
3D structure all at once,

or you can do a point-by-point
fabrication, where you create

every single aspect
in the crystal

by scanning the
whole 3D structure.

Or you can have a
layer-by-layer approach
to make a whole 3D structure.

So first example of
a full 3D fabrication
is to use colloidal particles.

So you can assemble colloidal
particles different ways.
You can either use--

you can either
micromanipulate your sphere

to put whatever sphere
you want, where you want.

Or you can use a self-assembly
property of colloidal particles

to make a whole
stack of particles,

and then you can do
different processes

to make a whole 3D
structure that can
be used as a photonic crystal.

Second full 3D
fabrication process

is to use what's called
holographic lithography.

So in this case, you have
four laser beams interfering,

and they create a whole 3D
interference pattern that can--

if you shine this
into a photoresist,

you would have some regions
which are exposed and some not.

And if you develop
your photoresist,

you would end up
having a whole 3D

structure that have been made,
like, in three-dimensional
all at once.

If you move on now to a
point-by-point fabrication

process, we can use
multiphoton polymerization,

in the sense where, here, you
can expose a single dot exactly
where you want.

So in this case,
if-- for example,

if you shine light with
a very tight focus point,

here you can have a
multiphoton polymerization

in your photoresist that a
single photon cannot achieve.

And so then, if you scan
your whole three-dimensional

structure, you can make
whatever shape you want.

And this is-- this
can be combined

with holographic lithography,
for example, where,

in the holographic lithography,
you make the whole 3D pattern.

And then, with multiphoton
polymerization,

you can put some defects
where you want or correct

for errors that
could have been made.

But another
promising approach is

to use a layer-by-layer
technique.
So this is an example.

It is called the woodpile
structure, as you can see.

So this is done
layer by layer, where

you pattern a whole
two-dimensional pattern

on your substrate,
and then you move
on building the whole stack.
And this here is not stable.

We have a FCC crystal lattice,
when every other layer
is shifted by half a period.

Another interesting
lattice we can

form with this
layer-by-layer approach

is the so-called-- the
holes-rods structure
we can see here on the right.

And how you can make these is
to use the same process of how

to-- patterning each layer at a
time and repeating the process,

and you actually have
these multiple layers
on top of each other.

And with this
technique, you can also

make defects in
whatever layer you want.

You can also use a
membrane-stacking technique.

So in this case, you pattern
all your 2D structure of your 2D

membranes first, and you
can make whatever shapes
you want, with defects or not.

And then you can
stack them together,

using some alignment
techniques, that
here is used by microspheres.

So basically, you come with
all these two-dimensional

structures, and you
stack them together

using these microspheres
for alignment.

Another promising technique to
align and stack this structure

is to use nanomagnets
on these membranes.

And these membranes
can help you first

to align each layer
on the others,

and also get-- the
magnetic force can

be used to break each
membrane from the main frame.

And if you want to build this--
one of these layers we can use

for the stacking, a
very promising technique

is to use coherent
diffraction lithography.

So here, we shine light through
a mask, which is a grating,

for example, and you
have your substrate

below at a specific position,
a specific height below,

which corresponds to one of
the Talbot planes, for example.

So here, you can see the
field below the mask, where

you can see different
Talbot plane,

and here is an example of
some self-imaging of a grating
at the first Talbot plane.

So that's one of
the main problems

is this-- to the
layer-by-layer fabrication is,

how accurate do you
need an alignment

to be between your
different 2D layers?

So that's really a big problem
with the fabrication of this 3D

photonic crystal, use this
layer-by-layer approach,

and that's why we
ran some simulations

to see how accurate
we need to be
in this layer-by-layer approach.
I got us--
COREY FUCETOLA: Yeah, thank you.
One second.
All right, thank you, Martin.

So one of the structures
that Martin mentioned

was the diamond
lattice, which is

just the same as the
face-center cubic,

but there's two
atoms in the middle.

So what I mean by that is
this atom and this atom.

This is actually eight
unit cells in this picture.

Now, this image
and this image were

taken from a program,
MIT Photonic-Bands,

which allows you to
calculate the bandgap
in three-dimensional structures.

For this particular structure,
the bandgap is 10.62%,

and this bandgap is actually
the range of frequencies here
divided by the mid frequency.

So that's what gives
us these percentages.

Now, one of the
things that we notice

is that it's
centered about 0.42,

and, obviously, the gap
is defined in this way.

What we are concerned
with is, what

happens if we change
this parameter delta?

So that corresponds to shifting
this sphere, this sphere,

this sphere, and this
sphere by an amount
delta in a linear direction.

So what we did was we
looked at, you know,

say it's 10%, 20%,
30%, 40%, what happens
to the overall bandgap?

And so these are the
simulations that I ran,

and you can see that
at no displacement,
you've got that nice bandgap.

And then, as you
shifted by 10%, the gap
decreases substantially.

And as you go beyond that,
the gap pretty much goes away.

So one of the things
that's curious

is what's happening in
this 0 to, say, 15% regime.

So we ran a final
simulation to give us that

and plotted the gap
normalized by that maximum gap

that you would get for
those percent displacements.

And you can see that at
around 5% displacement,

the gap's about 67% of
what it was originally.

So a small displacement
can substantially

affect your bandgap,
and to the extent

that you may want that, it's
not necessarily a bad thing.

But you need to be
aware of it when you're
engineering these things.

So these are just some
numbers that kind of

give you a better handle
on what that graph means.
But I like this one the best.

If you want to keep your
gap above 10% or 95%,

then that's really
a displacement

of around 1% to 2%,
which is pretty small.

So a real example of this
in the telecom wavelengths

and frequencies is, you know,
frequency is 1.9 times 10
to the 14 hertz.

And if you look at the
displacement in nanometers

now-- so we've multiplied
it by our lattice spacing--

in Sebastien's slides,
this was the r.

But in this case,
it's 663 nanometers.

You multiply the
percent by that number--

you find that the bandwidth
decreases rapidly as you go out
to, like, 40 or 60 nanometers.

The bandwidth has
dropped almost 50%.

So in this case, we might
want to narrow the bandgap

if we want to have a very,
very narrow band filter.

But we might want to have lots
of frequencies being reflected

from this particular
crystal, at which point

we'd want to be
operating over here.

So I hope that this gives
you a sense for how important

misalignment is and how
you can use it to engineer
your bandgap appropriately.
Thank you.
[APPLAUSE]
PROFESSOR: Questions?

AUDIENCE: One of the
things that was mentioned

was that certain
fabricating techniques will
allow you to put defects in.
Why would you want--

is it the same principle,
that you want--
COREY FUCETOLA: So if you--
MARTIN DETERRE: I got it.
You go ahead.

COREY FUCETOLA:
If you add defects

into the photonic crystal,
then essentially you'll

make a pass band in the bandgap,
and light can propagate.

If it's like a line defect,
you make a waveguide.

If it's like a point
defect, then light'll
resonate inside that defect.

And there's obviously other
structures you could do,

but those are two
of the simpler ones.

AUDIENCE: Is this current given
thickness of photonic crystal,

or is it like an infinite
photonic crystal?

COREY FUCETOLA: This is
actually one of my big caveats
about the simulation.

So this software assumes that
it's infinitely periodic,

and so what I've
done here is actually

shifted every other layer,
not just a single layer.

And that's an artifact of
the simulation software.

If I wanted to try and
model just one layer,

it becomes much, much
more complicated.

But, yeah, it is
infinite in extent.

And one of the things that
the holographic lithography is

limited by is the actual
thickness of the photoresist

that they can expose because
after a little while,

the light stops interfering
in the right way,

and you don't get
that interference
pattern that you want anymore.

AUDIENCE: In real life,
how could such a defect
come about--
COREY FUCETOLA: So--
AUDIENCE: --this displacement?

COREY FUCETOLA: Yeah,
there's a couple ways, right?

Now, one of the things
that Martin was showing

was this coherent diffraction
lithography stuff.

And I'm going to talk about it
a little bit because I know it
very well.

So you can imagine, if you
had your substrate at an angle

here, you pass through
a few Talbot planes.

And so the actual
shape of your grating
wouldn't be just periodic.

There'd be regions where you'd
go to frequency doubling.

There'd be regions
where you didn't.

So that alignment capability
is really an important thing.

And if you imagine stacking,
in the membrane-stacking sense,

these printed patterns
on top of each other,

you have to be able to
align those patterns
relative to each other.

And if your alignment is off
by, say, 25 nanometers, then

you get something like 25%
decrease in your bandgap.

So one of the examples
of misalignment

is actually in the stacking
part of the fabrication.
And one of the things that--

you know, in this
particular case,

this stacking was all dependent
on how good these spheres are.
So the misalignment's not--

I don't believe it was
reported in this paper,

but it could be 20
or 30 nanometers.
They don't say.

And so that's where the
misalignment comes from.

But, you know, in Minghao's
work, in this one,

the misalignment
comes from the e-beam.

So as the e-beam's writing
each one of these--

each one of these hole layers
or each one of these rod layers,

there's a certain few
nanometers-off error

that, you know, it misplaces
a rod, or it misplaces a hole.

So I guess the answer
to your question

is that there's a
lot of different ways

that misalignment
can happen, but it's
controlling that misalignment.

And if we use
diffractive optics,
we can control it very well.
AUDIENCE: I have [INAUDIBLE].
COREY FUCETOLA: Yeah.

AUDIENCE: So how
does a crystal that's

designed for a wider bandgap,
but has a misalignment,

so you have an
effectively shorter one,

how does that
compare to one that's

actually designed for
the smaller bandgap
and is accurately aligned?

COREY FUCETOLA: So I think
the answer to the question

is, if I were
designing it, I'd want

to go with the one that's
designed to have a smaller

bandgap without
misalignment than one that's

designed to have a smaller
gap with misalignment.

Like, I wouldn't
screw up my pattern
to make the bandgap get smaller.

I'd try and design it
to have that bandgap.
PROFESSOR: OK.
[APPLAUSE]
